revision.text:
[[File:Taiwan NASA Terra MODIS 23791.jpg|thumb|2002 Satellite view of Taiwan]] [[Taiwan]] is active geologically, formed on a complex [[convergent boundary]] between the [[Yangtze Plate|Yangtze Subplate]] of the [[Eurasian Plate]] to the west and north, the [[Okinawa Plate]] on the north-east, the [[Philippine Plate]] on the east and south, and the [[Sunda Plate]] to the southwest. [[Subduction]] changes direction at Taiwan. The upper part of the crust on the island is primarily made up of a series of [[terrane]]s, mostly old [[island arc]]s which have been forced together by the collision of the forerunners of the Eurasian Plate and the Philippine Sea Plate, which is moving to the northeast. These have been further uplifted as a result of the detachment of a portion of the Eurasian Plate as it was subducted beneath remnants of the Philippine Sea Plate, a process which left the crust under Taiwan more buoyant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geo.arizona.edu/~anderson/taiwan/tai_index.html |title=Geology of Taiwan — University of Arizona |website=Geo.arizona.edu |date= |accessdate=1 August 2010}}</ref>
South of Taiwan, the Philippine Sea Plate is subducting under the Sunda Plate, forming the [[Luzon Volcanic Arc]] (including [[Green Island, Taiwan|Green Island]] and [[Orchid Island]]). The east and south of the island are a complex system of belts formed by, and part of the zone of, active collision between the North Luzon Trough portion of the Luzon Volcanic Arc and the Eurasian Plate, where accreted portions of the Luzon Arc and Luzon forearc form the [[Haian Range|eastern Coastal Range]] and parallel inland [[Huatung Valley|Taitung Longitudinal Valley]] of Taiwan respectively.<ref>Clift, Schouten and Draut (2003) in ''Intra-Oceanic Subduction Systems: Tectonic and Magmatic Processes'', {{ISBN|1-86239-147-5}} p84–86</ref>
To the northeast, the Philippine Sea Plate is subducting under the Okinawa Plate, forming the [[Ryukyu]] Volcanic Arc.
{{ external media | align = right | width = | image1 = [http://volcano.gl.ntu.edu.tw/worldwide/taiwan_geologymap.htm Geology Map of Taiwan] }}
[[File:Taiwan seismicity.jpg|thumb|Taiwan [[seismicity]], showing both magnitude and depth of earthquakes.]]
==Terranes== [[File:Haian Range, Taiwan.jpg|thumb|[[Haian Range]]]] The [[Haian Range]] or Coastal Range [[terrane]] belongs to the [[Luzon Volcanic Arc]] (呂宋島火山弧), and is on the [[Philippine Sea Plate]] (菲律賓海板塊). West of this is the Longitudinal Valley or [[Huatung Valley]], an active depositional zone in a rift valley. West of this is the Eastern Central Range terrane, part of the continental base that has been upturned. The western side of the range is the Western Central Range terrane, which is metamorphosed earlier Tertiary clastic sediments. The '''Lishan Fault''' separates the Hsuehshan Range terrane Eocene to Oligocene sandstone and shale. The '''Chukou Fault''' (觸口斷層) provides the boundary for the Western Foothills terrane, which is shallow marine detritus from Miocene to Pleistocene. A deformation front forms the boundary with the undeformed coastal plains alluvium, which is still depositing.<ref name=ma/>
The Eastern Central Range terrane can be divided into the Tailuko belt on the west with greenschist metamorphism and the Yuli belt on the east with blueschist metamorpism. The two metamorphic belts are possibly separated by a fault called Shoufeng fault, but this is unproven.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_15.jsp |title=Metamorphc Belts |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215025512/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_15.jsp |archivedate=2010-12-15 |df= }}</ref>
==Central Mountains== [[File:Central Range.jpg|thumb|[[Central Mountain Range]]]]
The oldest exposed rocks are heavily metamorphosed and found in the Central Mountains.<ref name=goc>{{cite book|title=Geology of China|chapter=Geology of Taiwan Province|authors=Zhang Jinhai and He Lishi|isbn=7-116-02268-6|publisher=Geological Publishing House|year=2002}}</ref> Poor quality fossil evidence suggests an origin in the [[Permian]] Period. They form a band of rock from [[Nan-ao, Yilan|Nan'ao]] in the north to inland of [[Jinfeng, Taitung|Jinfeng]] on the eastern flank of the [[Central Mountain Range]]. The band is 30 km wide in the north and narrows to the south.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eastern Central Range Introduction |url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_1.jsp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524180702/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_1.jsp |archivedate=2011-05-24 |df= }}</ref> These earlier rocks are heavily metamorphosed. They also occur as a basement beneath the western part of the island. They make up the '''Danana'ao Group''' or Tananao Schist. This group consists of the Kainanagang Gneiss, Tailuge Marble, and Changchun Schist.
The Yuli Schist is [[Cretaceous]] in age and consists of black schist and some [[greenschist]], [[glaucophane]] [[schist]], and spotted [[slate]]. It is the easternmost part and extends from Chian southwards to the west of the Chihpen hot springs in a belt about 150 km long. Although the dark colour of the black schist is due to carbon, carbon is less than 2% of the content. The minerals found are quartz, [[mica]], [[Chlorite group|chlorite]], [[albite]], [[sphene]], and [[graphite]].<ref name=lomr>{{cite web|title=Eastern Central Range Occurrence and Lithology of Metamorphic Rocks |url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_12.jsp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215025437/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_12.jsp |archivedate=2010-12-15 |df= }}</ref>
The Changchun Schist being mostly [[greenschist]] is found on the western side and forms thick beds. It is found along with smaller amounts of [[chert]], and black schist. The rock is foliated dark green rock containing chlorite, [[epidote]], quartz, calcite, biotite, albite and [[actinolite]]. They are derived from [[mafic]] [[volcanic rock]]s. These rocks can host [[copper sulfide]] ores.<ref name=lomr/>
Siliceous schists are coloured grey, they are metamorphosed sandstone, rich in quartz. [[Quartzite]] and chert bands can be found, and they are commonly associated with the black schist.
The Chiuchu Formation or Tailuge Marble forms a band from Tailuko in the north to a point between Wulu and Kuanshan in the south. The [[limestone]] is mined in quarries south of Suao for cement manufacture. Although the colour is usually a shade of grey, there are also black or white limestone, which is chopped into blocks for building purposes. [[Dolostone|Dolomite]] is also found along with the limestone particularly at [[Chingchangshan]], [[Hopingchi]], and [[Mukuashan]].<ref name=lomr/>
The Kainangan Gneiss or Kanagan Formation occurs in several elongated bodies. The [[gneiss]] derived from sedimentary rocks contains coarse grained quartz, biotite, and albitic plagioclase. There is also orthogneiss derived from [[granite]]. This is light grey and contains sodic plagioclase, quartz, biotite, and muscovite. Within the gneiss there are [[pegmatite]] [[Dike (geology)|dikes]] containing quartz, feldspar and mica.<ref name=lomr/>
Other igneous rocks found in the old metamorphic belt are [[amphibolite]] and [[dolerite]] dikes. [[Serpentinite]] is found 5 km west of Fengtien (奉天). It contains exploited deposits of [[nephrite]], [[talc]] and [[asbestos]]. [[Wanjung, Hualien|Wanjung Station]] (萬榮) is close to more outcrops of serpentenite. Tamayenshan block northwest of [[Juisui, Hualien|Juisui]] (瑞穗) and the Tsenghuanshan block 10 km west of Juisui are significant [[ultramafic]] outcrops.<ref name=lomr/>
Green serpentinite from near [[Yuli, Hualien|Yuli]] makes a good quality building stone. A band of ultramafic rocks extends for 25 km north of [[Litao, Taitung]] (離島).<ref name=lomr/>
The area was subjected to the Nanao Orogeny around 85 Ma which involved the granite intrusion and regional metamorphism. Rifting that opened the [[South China Sea]] around 40 Ma may be connected with some dolerite intrusions. The Penglai Orogeny started about 10 Ma and continues at the present time.<ref name=ecrra>{{cite web|title=Eastern Central Range Radiometric Ages |url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_14.jsp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215025250/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_14.jsp |archivedate=2010-12-15 |df= }}</ref>
==Eastern stratigraphic region== The most recently added part of the island is the [[Haian Range|Coastal Range]] on the east coast from [[Taitung City]] in the south to Hualien City in the north. The range is the continuation of the Luzon arc. The age is [[Neogene]] and the rock consist of [[Mélange|melange]] and [[volcaniclastic]]s. The rock units are firstly Chimei Volcanics Miocene [[andesite]]. Next is the Tuluanshan Formation, consisting of [[tuff]], then Takangou Formation, consisting of sediments such as shale and sandstone that contain volcanic particles. The Lichi Formation consists of melange. It is made of mud containing blocks of other stone such as sandstone and [[ophiolite]]. It is found on the southern half of the west side of the Coastal range. When this erodes, [[badlands]] are formed. Because it is a mixture of stone, the Lichi Formation is hard to date, but is likely to be from [[Pliocene]].<ref name=ecrsal>{{cite web|url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_22.jsp |title=Eastern Coastal Range Stratigraphy and Lithology |author=Central Geological Survey MOEI |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927123537/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_eastern_22.jsp |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
The Pinanshan [[Conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] is found on Pinanshan Hill and along the Pinantachi stream north of [[Taitung City|Taitung]] (台東). The constituents are 5–15 cm cobbles erodes by freshwater from the Central Range. It formed somewhere from middle to late Pleistocene, and indicates the plate collision had taken place.<ref name=ecrsal/>
The Milun Conglomerate is to the north of Hualien. This has also gone under the names of Beiron Conglomerate Formation and Milunpi Conglomerate. It is tilted at 30°. It is undated but is likely from Pleistocene.<ref name=ecrsal/>
==Central Mountains strata== Shibachongxi Formation is from the Eocene consisting of slate and then beds of metamorphosed sandstone. The total thickness is up to 1000 m.<ref name=goc/>
Dajian Formation consists of sandstone from the upper Eocene, up to 2700 meters thick.<ref name=goc/>
Xichun Formation slate and [[phyllite]] is from the lower Oligocene. The thickness is from 0.6 to 3 km.<ref name=goc/>
Siling Formation coarse sandstone in thick beds is from the Oligocene.<ref name=goc/>
Shuichungliu Formation form the Oligocene contains [[argillaceous]] slate and [[graywacke]].<ref name=goc/>
Bilushan Formation contains slate and phyllite from the Eocene.<ref name=goc/>
Lushan Formation from the Miocene contains shale slate and sandstone.<ref name=goc/>
Aodi Formation contemporary
Sule Formation slate and sandstone from the later Miocene.
==Western stratigraphic region== The west part of the island exposes deformed and metamorphosed [[Cenozoic]] sediments, overlaid by [[Quaternary]] piedmont region in the flat plains on the west coast.
[[Cretaceous]], [[Paleocene]] and Eocene deposits are not exposed on the surface, but are buried. They have been discovered by drilling.
The Yunlin Formation is from the Cretaceous and only known from boreholes. The rocks are siltstone, basalt, shale and limestone.
The Paleocene Wangong Formation consisting of [[volcaniclastic]]s, sandstone, shale and limestone is over 1046 meters thick.
In the [[Eocene]] the Shuangji Formation formed mostly from volcanic particles in the form of tuff and tuffaceous sandstone. These beds are from 100 m to 3 km thick.
In the [[Oligocene]] the Wuzhishan Formation or Wuchihshan Formation (五指山組) formed thick beds of sandstone. The total thickness is 0.9 to 1.2 km.
The Yeliu Group from the [[Miocene]] is fine grained sandstone, with some beds of shale, basaltic tuff and three seams of [[coal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=ftp://52jyw.com/%B5%E7%D7%D3%CD%BC%CA%E9/035/T/A2038224.pdf |title=Tertiary in Petroliferous Regions of China }}</ref> Possibly including Wushan Formation, Piling Shale, Peiliao Formation, Talu shale, Shihti Formation, Kuanyiongshan sandstone.<ref name=acc/>
The Ruifang Group contains beds of sandstone, siltstone, shale and six thin coal beds. These beds are 0.8 to 1.6 km thick.
The Sangxia Group starts with medium grained sandstone, but in the upper layers increases shale. Eight thin coal seams are included. The total thickness of the deepest beds exceeds 5 km. This includes the Kueichulin Formation with the Yutengping Sandstone, Shihliufen Shale, Kuantaoshan Sandstone; the Nanchuang Formation including Shangfuchi Sandstone and Tungkeng Formation.<ref name=acc/>
The Jinshui Formation or Chinshui Formation from the [[Pliocene]] is mostly shale interbedded with some [[mudstone]] and sandstone is between 80 and 400 m thick.
The Zhuolan Formation or Cholan Formation (卓蘭層) starts in the Pliocene and extends into the first stage of the [[Pleistocene]]. It consists of fine grained sandstone. This is 1.5 to 2.5 km thick. At the same time on the southern tip of the island, the Kending Formation or Kenting Formation (墾丁組) was formed consisting of mudstone with [[ophiolite]] [[Mélange|melange]].<ref name=ghp>{{cite web|title=Geology of the Hungchun Peninsula|url=http://www.gl.ntu.edu.tw/model/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=30&limit=1&limitstart=1|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724235434/http://www.gl.ntu.edu.tw/model/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=21&Itemid=30&limit=1&limitstart=1|archivedate=2011-07-24|df=}}</ref> The ophiolite melange contains pebbles and blocks of Miocene age consisting of basic and ultrabasic rock from the ocean floor. The interpretation is that a wedge of seafloor was pushed above sea level, eroded and dropped fragments into the mud.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Kenting Melange and its Record of Tectonic Events |author1=Benjamin M. Page |author2=Ching-Ying Lan |journal=Memoir of the Geological Society of China |url=http://twgeoref.2002.moeacgs.gov.tw/storage/1983/19830243/Eab.PDF |date=May 1983 |issue=5 |pages=227–248 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305083225/http://twgeoref.2002.moeacgs.gov.tw/storage/1983/19830243/eab.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
The Toukoshan Formation (Toukeshan) (頭嵙山層) commenced with fine sandstone with thin beds of conglomerate, and continued into mainly conglomerate with sandstone beds. This was formed in stage 1 and 2 of the Pleistocene. It is from 0.4 to 3 km thick.
The Szekou Formation is a light bluish gray siltstone, with shale and fine grained sandstone. The Maanshan Formation is very similar. It is overlain by Hengchun Limestone and may interfinger.<ref name=ghp/>
==Western piedmont region== The Hengchun Limestone was formed after the Penglai movement in the third Pleistocene stage. Also at this time [[laterite]] (紅土) and gravel on [[river terrace]]s was formed. [[Holocene]] mud sand and coral form a wide belt on the west side of the island.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Journal of Tropical Oceanography|date=February 2004| title=Cretaceous and Tertiary Palynofloras in Taiwan Area and its Correlation with those in Neighbouring Coastal Regions of Mainland China|authors=SONG Zhi-chen, HUANG Fei }}</ref>
==Volcanic rocks== {{ external media | align = right | image1 = [http://volcano.gl.ntu.edu.tw/worldwide/taiwan_volcanomap.htm Volcanic Distribution Map] }}
The [[Tatun Volcano Group]] is found on the northern tip of Taiwan. [[Qixing Mountain (Taipei)|Chihsingshan]] is the highest point of the volcanoes at 1120 meters. The volcanoes have formed the rounded shape of the northern cape of Taiwan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_setting.jsp |publisher=Central Geological Survey |title=Geographic Setting |work=Geology of Taiwan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524175532/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_setting.jsp |archivedate=24 May 2011 }}</ref> The volcanic rock also occur on Huaping Isle, Mienhua Isle, [[Pengjia Islet|Pengchia Isle]] and Huangwei Isle just to the north of Taiwan. The rocks are aluminium rich [[andesite]], [[tuff]] and [[breccia]]. The rocks are poor in sodium and magnesium, but rich in iron, potassium, rubidium and strontium and strong in rare earth elements. The magma was derived by melting of the underthrust sea plate behind the [[Ryukyu arc|Ryukyu Volcanic Arc]] during the [[Pleistocene]].<ref name=goc/>
The Caolingshan Basalt consists of olivine and pyroxene, with crystals of biotite and plagioclase. This is rich in K, Rb, Mg, Sr, Cr, and Ni, but poor in Na, Al, and Fe. Rare earth elements are strongly enriched. The magma was derived by deep mantle melting of the underthrust sea plate behind the Ryukyu Volcanic Arc during the Pleistocene.<ref name=goc/>
The [[Chilung Volcano Group|volcanoes on Chilungshan]], Penshan, Caoshan, [[Chilung Island]] (Keelung Islet) and [[Gueishan Island]] date from the Pleistocene period and later. The eruption were explosive [[tholeiitic]] andesite and [[dacite]]. The main mineral is calcium rich [[plagioclase]]. The magma source is the western extremity of the Ryukyu Volcanic Arc formed when the [[subducting]] [[Philippines Sea Plate]] was compressed below the edge of the Eurasian Plate at about 20 to 30 km deep. The magma was contaminated with continental crust material. Geochemistry of the rock shows that iron, aluminium, titanium, potassium, rubidium and strontium are enriched, but sodium, magnesium and nickel are impoverished.<ref name=goc/>
Alkaline volcanic rocks from north west Taiwan are found at the [[Shihmen Dam|Shihmen Reservoir]], Chiaopanshan, [[Taoyuan City|Taoyuan]] and Fuxing. The rocks are [[picrite]], [[alkaline basalt]] and [[trachyandesite]]. The commons minerals are [[albite]], [[olivine]], [[clinopyroxene]] and oxides of iron and titanium. The elements enriched are sodium and titanium, and magnesium and calcium are reduced. The rock dates from the Miocene. The magma was formed under tension conditions on the continental margin from deep down in the mantle.<ref name=goc/>
Volcanoes on the Coastal Range and [[Green Island, Taiwan|Green Island]] erupted tholeiite andesite, and volcanic explosive fragments. The volcanoes erupted from the [[Pliocene]] to Pleistocene period. It is part of the [[Luzon Volcanic Arc]]. Magma was formed from subducting [[oceanic crust]] under compression about 25 km deep. The andesite rock contains some visible crystals of [[pyroxene]] or [[amphibole]]. The [[geochemistry]] of the rock shows it is enriched in [[potassium]], [[strontium]] and [[rubidium]] and [[LREE|light rare earth elements]]. Chromium and nickel are depleted.<ref name=goc/> The Chimei Volcanic Complex, near the [[Xiuguluan River|Hsiukuluanchi River]], has an age from 9 to 22.2 Ma. It is associated with [[copper porphyry]] mineralisation. It covers an area of 22 km<sup>2</sup>.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gl.ntu.edu.tw/model/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=20&Itemid=30 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724235448/http://www.gl.ntu.edu.tw/model/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=20&Itemid=30 |archivedate=2011-07-24 |df= }}</ref>
Pleistocene basalt and tholeiite is found in the [[Penghu Islands]]. The lava erupted from fissures in a flood. The rock is enriched in titanium and poor in aluminium, rubidium and strontium. The alkaline basalt contains olivine and [[analcite]]. The tholeiite contains plagioclase and pyroxene. The magma originated in the upper mantle under tension conditions on the continental margin.<ref name=goc/>
==Structures== *Hengchun Valley [[syncline]] under the Hengchun Valley<ref name=ghp/> *Hengchun Fault on east side of Hengchun Valley. It extends along the Pintung Valley as the Chaochow fault and Laonungchi fault.<ref name=ghp/> *Kenting Park [[anticline]] is overturned and folds Miocene rocks of the Changlo Formation, Lushan Formation to the north. Loshui Formation is on the sides of the anticline.<ref name=ghp/>
==Tectonics== The Philippines Sea Plate is converging with the continent at 7 cm per year in the west north west direction. It has compressed Cenozoic sediments by around 200 km in the last 4 [[Year#SI_prefix_multipliers|Ma]]. The piled up sediment is rising into mountains at the rate of 5 mm per year.<ref name=goc/>
The major seismic faults in Taiwan correspond to the various suture zones between the various terranes. As a result, Taiwan has numerous [[mud volcano]]es and [[hot spring]]s. These faults have produced [[List of earthquakes in Taiwan|several major quakes]] throughout the history of the island, including the [[1951 East Rift Valley earthquakes]] on the East Rift Valley (花東縱谷) and [[1964 Baihe earthquake]] on the Chukou Fault. The [[1946 Hsinhua earthquake]] ruptured the Hsinhua fault (新化斷層). The most lethal was [[1935 Hsinchu-Taichung earthquake]] shifting on a fault at [[Emei, Hsinchu|Emei Township]], [[Hsinchu County]]. The second deadliest was a 7.3 quake that ruptured the Chelongpu Fault (車籠埔斷層) on 21 September 1999, known as the "[[1999 Jiji earthquake|921 earthquake]]". On 4 March 2010 at about 01:20 UTC, [[2010 Taiwan earthquake|a magnitude 6.4 earthquake]] hit southern Taiwan.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/03/03/taiwan.quake/index.html?hpt=T1 | title = 6.4-magnitude quake hits southern Taiwan | first1 = Christine | last1 = Theodorou | first2 = Andrew | last2 =Lee | accessdate = 4 March 2010 | date = 3 March 2010| work = CNN.com }}</ref> The [[seismic hazard map]] for Taiwan by the USGS shows 9/10 of the island as the highest rating (most hazardous).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seismo.ethz.ch/GSHAP/eastasia/asiafin.gif |title=USGS seismic hazard map of Eastern Asia |website=Seismo.ethz.ch |date= |accessdate=2011-05-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000303055258/http://seismo.ethz.ch/gshap/eastasia/asiafin.gif |archivedate=2000-03-03 |df= }}</ref>
==Offshore== The offshore features include the Kaoping Slope extending off the southwest coast of Taiwan into the South China Sea. This is emerging from the sea over time to extend the island. <ref name=ma>{{cite web|url=http://www.geo.arizona.edu/~anderson/taiwan/intro.html|author=Megan Anderson|date=5 March 2001|title=Introduction to Geologic Features|work=Taiwan: An Active Continental Subduction Zone}}</ref>
The Henchung Ridge extends south from the [[Hengchun Peninsula]] (恆春半島), and is the submarine part of the Central Range. The Southern Longitudinal Trough is the southern underwater extension of the [[Huatung Valley|Longitudinal Valley]]. The Huatang Ridge extends south off the coast from [[Taitung City]]. The Taitung Trough lies to the east behind the Luzon Arc. The Luzon Arc comes to the surface on the islands of [[Lüdao]] and [[Orchid Island|Lanyu]]. A submarine canyon, the Taitung Canyon, cuts through the arc between the two islands linking the Taitung Trough to the Huatung Basin.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Tectonic Significance of the Taitung Canyon, Huatung Basin, East of Taiwan|journal=Marine Geophysical Research|volume=25|issue=1–2|pages=95–107|doi=10.1007/s11001-005-0736-2|bibcode = 2004MarGR..25...95S |year=2005|first1=Jean-Claude|last1=Sibuet|first2=Shu-Kun|last2=Hsu|first3=Alain|last3=Normand}}</ref> The canyon cuts across the Huatung Basin bending to the north and reaching the [[Ryukyu Trench]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://tao.cgu.org.tw/pdf/v93p453.pdf |title=Structural Controls on the Taitung Canyon in the Huatung Basin East of Taiwan |journal=TAO |volume=9 |issue=3 |date=September 1998 |pages=453–479 |author1=Philippe Schnurle |author2=Char-Shine Liu |author3=Serge E. Lallemand |author4=Donald Reed |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830124938/http://tao.cgu.org.tw/pdf/v93p453.pdf |archivedate=2011-08-30 |df= }}</ref> A 5.5 magnitude earthquake struck at 08:00 GMT on 20 March 2011, near the canyon<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc00027dc.php#details |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-08-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324004914/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc00027dc.php#details#details |archive-date=2011-03-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> breaking segments C and D of the [[EAC-C2C (cable system)|East Asia Crossing]] undersea cable. The '''Huatung Basin''' lies east of Taiwan south of the city of Hualien. It extends west till the [[Gagua Ridge]] about 110 km offshore.<ref name=ma/>
The Taiwan Banks are a shallow part of the main continental shelf off mainland China lying to the south and south west of [[Penghu Islands]].<ref name=ma/> The [[Taixinan Basin]] (台西南盆地) is located between Taiwan Banks and the Central Mountains.
The [[Okinawa Trough]], the [[back-arc basin]] behind the [[Ryukyu Islands]], shows up on the coastline as a bay between Dome Point north to Sanshokiaku (easternmost point of Taiwan) (24.6° to 25°N).<ref name=ma/>
==Geophysics== Taiwan has a very strong, positive [[Bouguer gravity anomaly]] in the Coastal Range, at over +4x10<sup>−4</sup> ms<sup>−2</sup>. A local low below -2x10<sup>−4</sup> ms<sup>−2</sup> is on the western side centered near [[Zhuolan, Miaoli|Zhoulan]].<ref name="Geology of China page 62">Geology of China page 62</ref> The gravity low is due to a mass deficit in the [[Taiwan Strait]] which is a [[flexural basin]].<ref name=acc>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8sqMGwkFtxAC&pg=PA11|page=2|title=Geology and geophysics of an arc-continent collision, Taiwan|editor=Char-Shine Liu|author1=Ying-Wei Chou |author2=Ho-Shing Yu |chapter=Structural Expressions of Flexural Extension in the Arc-continent Collisional Foredeep of Western Taiwan|isbn=9780813723587|date=2002-01-01}}</ref>
Positive magnetic variations are found in narrow strips, west-southwest oriented of the west coast, and east-northeast off the northern coast, and south-north offshore from the Coastal Range heading south. These are of the order of 200 nT.<ref>Geology of China page 66</ref>
The Crustal thickness is around 30 km, with over 2 km of thickening under the Central Range, and thinning off the east coast. Taiwan is on the edge of the continental shelf, so the thickness of the crust is constant through the Taiwan Strait to the mainland.<ref name="Geology of China page 62"/>
Heat flow is greatest to west of the Longitudinal Valley at rates exceeding 240 mWm<sup>−2</sup>.
==Hydrology== [[File:Beitou Hot Spring Valley.jpg|thumb|right|Beitou hot spring valley]] Many of the rocks in Taiwan have low pore space and have little ground water.
There are several hot springs in Taiwan, with most around the northern volcanic region. The Chingshui geothermal region is named after the [[Cingshuei River]] 13 km south west of [[Yilan City|Yilan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pangea.stanford.edu/ERE/pdf/IGAstandard/SGW/2006/fan.pdf|title=Evaluation of Natural Recharge of Chingshui Geothermal Reservoir in Taiwan|author=K. C. Fan|date=30 January 2006|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Rivers in Taiwan transport a large amount of sediment to the sea. The south end of the Longitudonal Valley discharges the [[Peinan River]] with 88,000,000 tons of sediment per year. East flowing rivers move 17, 15 31 and 22 megatons per year of sediment. The [[Zhuoshui River|Cho Shiu]] shifts 54 MT per year. Rivers running south from the Central Range move over 100 MT of sediment per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.springerimages.com/Images/Geosciences/1-10.1007_s10064-009-0209-y-35|title=Home - Springer|website=Springerimages.com|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref>
==Study== ===Mapping=== The first [[geological map]] of Taiwan was made in 1898 by Y. Ishii titled ''A Map of Geology and Mineral Resources of the Island of Taiwan''. It was at a scale of 1:800,000 and showed six items in its legend.<ref name=egm>{{cite web|url=http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_map.jsp |title=Earlier Geologic Maps Of Taiwan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524180608/http://www.moeacgs.gov.tw/english/twgeol/twgeol_map.jsp |archivedate=2011-05-24 |df= }}</ref> Japan needed oil and coal for the war against Russia in 1904, so study began on the coal fields in the north part of Taiwan, more detailed maps were made, and the next one was published in 1911 by Y. Deguchi and G. Hosoya at a scale of 1:300,000.<ref name=egm/> A third map was produced in 1926 titled: ''Geological Map of Taiwan showing Mineral Distribution'' by Y. Ichikawa and H. Takahashi.<ref name=egm/> It showed 19 rock units.<ref name=egm/> A 1935 coloured map by Y. Ichikawa had a scale of 1:500,000.<ref name=egm/> In 1953 the [[Geological Survey of Taiwan]] (台灣地質調查所) published a map compiled by L.S. Chang at a 1:300,000 scale. A 1974 map had two scales 1:250,000 and 1:500,000.<ref name=egm/> A second edition was printed in 1986 along with notes.<ref name=egm/>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{commons category|Geology of Taiwan}}
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://eng.wra.gov.tw/public/Data/gh012_p3.htm|year=2000|title=Geologic Map of Taiwan|publisher=Central Geological Survey, Ministry of Economic Affairs|author1=Chao-Hsia Chen|author2=Hsin-Chang HoKai-Shuan Shei|display-authors=etal|access-date=2011-03-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815172111/http://eng.wra.gov.tw/public/Data/gh012_p3.htm#|archive-date=2011-08-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}

revision.text:
A '''glacial boundary''' is a line on a map representing the farthest advance of a [[glacier]] that has retreated. It generally refers to the extent of continental, rather than alpine, glaciers.
In the northern hemisphere, glaciers advanced from the north during the [[Pleistocene]] epoch. The glacial boundary thus represents the farthest southern extent of the glaciers at that time.
In North America, the boundary from the most recent ice sheet passes through the states of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota, Montana, and Washington. It also crosses the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–US border]] in several locations.
See [[Timeline of glaciation]].
See the U.S. [https://web.archive.org/web/20081205020547/http://www.nationalatlas.gov/ National Atlas] for a [https://web.archive.org/web/20060106165939/http://nationalatlas.gov/articles/geology/features/glaciallimit.html map of the boundary] in North America.
[[Category:Cartography]]
[[Category:Glaciology]]

revision.text:
{{short description|A natural feature of the solid surface of the Earth or other planetary body}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2012}} [[File:Cono de Arita, Salta. (Argentina).jpg|thumb|This [[conical hill]] in [[Salar de Arizaro]], [[Salta Province|Salta]], [[Argentina]] called Cono de Arita constitutes a landform.]] A '''landform''' is a natural feature of the solid surface of the Earth or other [[planetary body]]. Landforms together make up a given [[terrain]], and their arrangement in the landscape is known as [[topography]]. Typical landforms include [[hill]]s, [[mountain]]s, [[plateau]]s, [[canyon]]s, and [[valley]]s, as well as [[shoreline]] features such as [[bay]]s, [[peninsula]]s, and [[sea]]s,{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} including submerged features such as [[mid-ocean ridge]]s, [[volcanoes]], and the great [[ocean basin]]s.
==Physical characteristics== Landforms are categorized by characteristic physical attributes such as elevation, slope, orientation, [[Stratum|stratification]], rock exposure, and soil type. Gross physical features or landforms include intuitive elements such as [[berm]]s, [[mound]]s, [[hill]]s, [[ridge]]s, [[cliff]]s, [[valley]]s, [[river]]s, [[peninsula]]s, [[volcano]]es, and numerous other structural and size-scaled (i.e. [[pond]]s vs. [[lake]]s, [[hill]]s vs. [[mountain]]s) elements including various kinds of inland and oceanic [[Waterbody|waterbodies]] and sub-surface features.
{{wide image|Cades Cove Panorama.JPG|600px|This panorama in [[Great Smoky Mountains National Park]] has the readily identifiable '''physical features''' of a rolling [[plain]], actually part of a broad [[valley]], distant [[hill|foothills]], and a backdrop of the old, much [[weathering|weathered]] [[Appalachian Mountains|Appalachian mountain range]]}}
==Hierarchy of classes== [[File:1 li jiang guilin yangshuo 2011.jpg|thumb|[[Karst|Karst towers]] landforms along [[Lijiang River]], [[Guilin]], [[China]]]]
[[Ocean]]s and [[continent]]s exemplify the highest-order landforms. [[Landform element]]s are parts of a high-order landforms that can be further identified and systematically given a cohesive definition such as hill-tops, shoulders, saddles, foreslopes and backslopes.
Some generic landform elements including: pits, peaks, channels, ridges, passes, pools and plains.
[[Terrain]] (or ''relief'') is the third or vertical dimension of ''land surface''. [[Topography]] is the study of terrain, although the word is often used as a synonym for relief itself. When relief is described [[underwater]], the term [[bathymetry]] is used. In [[cartography]], many [[Cartographic relief depiction|different techniques]] are used to describe relief, including [[contour line]]s and TIN ([[Triangulated irregular network]]).
Elementary landforms (segments, facets, relief units) are the smallest homogeneous divisions of the land surface, at the given scale/resolution. These are areas with relatively homogeneous [[morphometric]] properties, bounded by lines of discontinuity. A plateau or a hill can be observed at various scales ranging from few hundred meters to hundreds of kilometers. Hence, the spatial distribution of landforms is often scale-dependent as is the case for soils and geological strata.
A number of factors, ranging from [[plate tectonics]] to [[erosion]] and [[deposition (sediment)|deposition]], can generate and affect landforms. [[biology|Biological]] factors can also influence landforms— for example, note the role of [[vegetation]] in the development of [[dune]] systems and [[salt marsh]]es, and the work of [[coral]]s and [[alga]]e in the formation of [[reef|coral reefs]].
Landforms do not include man-made features, such as [[canal]]s, [[port]]s and many [[harbor]]s; and geographic features, such as [[desert]]s, [[forest]]s, and [[grassland]]s. Many of the terms are not restricted to refer to features of the planet [[Earth]], and can be used to describe surface features of other planets and similar objects in the [[Universe]]. Examples are mountains, hills, polar caps, and valleys, which are found on all of the [[terrestrial planets]].
The scientific study of landforms is known as [[geomorphology]].
==Recent developments== Landforms may be extracted from a [[digital elevation model]] using some automated techniques where the data has been gathered by modern satellites and [[stereoscopic]] [[aerial photography|aerial surveillance]] cameras.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/research/cires/banff/pubpapers/198/ |title=Conference paper: "Automated landform classification using DEMs"|accessdate=2008-06-26|author1=Robert A. MacMillan |author2=David H. McNabb |author3=R. Keith Jones |date=September 2000}}</ref> Until recently, compiling the data found in such data sets required time consuming and expensive techniques involving many man-hours. The most detailed DEMs available are measured directly using [[LIDAR]] techniques.
==See also==
* {{portal inline|size=tiny|Landforms}} * [[Geomorphology]] * [[Land]] * [[List of landforms]] * [[Open-geomorphometry project]] * [[Terrain]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Landforms}} {{Wiktionary}} *[https://code.google.com/p/open-geomorphometry-project/ Open-Geomorphometry Project]
{{Earth's landforms}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}}
'''Government in Tasmania''' is delivered by a number of '''agencies''', grouped under areas of portfolio responsibility. Each portfolio is led by a [[Minister (government)|government minister]] who is a member of the [[Parliament of Tasmania]], appointed by the [[Governor of Tasmania|Governor]] as the representative of the [[Monarchy of Australia|Crown]].
The agencies are principally grouped as eight departments, each led by a [[Departmental secretary|secretary]] or [[director-general]] and comprising a number of portfolios covering specific policy areas across the department and allocated statutory authorities, trading enterprises, boards, councils and other public bodies.
Agencies have varying levels of operational autonomy, and deliver one or more of frontline public services, administrative functions and law enforcement. Some are structured as for-profit corporations. Where there are multiple portfolios within a department, directors-general may be accountable to a number of ministers.
All agencies are identifiable by their corporate logo, which features in agency advertising, publications and correspondence, pictured right.
A list of articles on Tasmanian government agencies sorted alphabetically is available at [[:Category:Government agencies of Tasmania|Government agencies of Tasmania]]. The Tasmanian government maintains a list of agencies and their contact details [http://www.service.tas.gov.au/GovOrgs/ at its website].
==Education== The '''[[Department of Education (Tasmania)|Department of Education]]''' (DoE) is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the Minister for Education and Training, presently the Hon. [[Jeremy Rockliff]] MP.
The Department is led by its Secretary, Jenny Gale.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.education.tas.gov.au/documentcentre/Documents/Organisational-Chart-Department-of-Education.pdf |title=Organisational chart |work=[[Department of Education (Tasmania)|Department of Education]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department of Education is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.education.tas.gov.au/About_us/Pages/Our-Structure.aspx |title=Boards and Advisory Groups|work=[[Department of Education (Tasmania)|Department of Education]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * Allport Library and Museum of Fine Arts Management Committee * Schools Registration Board * Skills Tasmania * State Library and Archives Trust * Tasmanian Aboriginal Corporation for Education (TACE) * Tasmanian Assessment, Standards and Certification (TASC) * Tasmanian Building and Construction Industry Training Board * Tasmanian Home Education Advisory Council * [[Tasmanian Institute of Agriculture]] * Tasmanian Library Advisory Board * Teachers Registration Board * University of Tasmania Council {{div col end}}
==Health and Human Services== The '''[[Department of Health and Human Services (Tasmania)|Department of Health and Human Services]]''' (DHHS) is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the Minister for Health, presently the Hon. [[Michael Ferguson (Australian politician)|Michael Ferguson]] MP; supported by the Minister for Human Services and the Minister for Women, presently the Hon. [[Jacquie Petrusma]] MP.
The Department is led by its Secretary, currently acting in the role, Michael Pervan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dhhs.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/204395/DHHS_Annual_Report_2014-15.pdf |title=DHHS Annual Report 2014-15 – Part 1 – Overview |work=[[Department of Health and Human Services (Tasmania)|Department of Health and Human Services]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=October 2015 |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department of Health and Human Services is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dhhs.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/88683/DHHS_Org_Chart_Sep15_v8.pdf |title=Organisational chart |work=[[Department of Health and Human Services (Tasmania)|Department of Health and Human Services]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=September 2015 |accessdate=15 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316094654/http://www.dhhs.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/88683/DHHS_Org_Chart_Sep15_v8.pdf# |archive-date=16 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *[[Ambulance Tasmania]] *Housing Tasmania *Tasmanian Health Service
==Justice== The '''Department of Justice''' (DoJ) is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the [[Attorney-General of Tasmania|Attorney-General]], the Minister for Justice, and the Minister for Corrections, presently the Hon. [[Vanessa Goodwin]] MLC; and the Minister for Planning and Local Government and the Minister for Building and Construction, presently the Hon. [[Peter Gutwein]] MP.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.tas.gov.au/about |title=About the Department of Justice |work=Department of Justice |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department is led by its Secretary, Simon Overland.<ref name=DoJorgchart>{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.tas.gov.au/about/organisation_structure |title=Department of Justice Organisation Chart |work=Department of Justice |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department of Justice is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref name=DoJorgchart/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Anti-Discrimination Tribunal *Asbestos Compensation Tribunal *[[Coroners Court of Tasmania]] *Equal Opportunity Tasmania *Forest Practices Tribunal *Guardianship & Administration Board *Health Practitioners Tribunal *Legal Aid Commission *[[Magistrates' Court of Tasmania]] *Mental Health Tribunal *Office of the Public Guardian *Resource Management & Planning Appeal Tribunal *[[Supreme Court of Tasmania]] *[[Tasmanian Electoral Commission]] *Tasmanian Industrial Commission *Tasmanian Planning Commission *Tasmania Prison Service *Workers Rehabilitation & Compensation Tribunal *WorkSafe Tasmania {{div col end}}
==Police, Fire and Emergency Management== The '''Department of Police, Fire and Emergency Management''' (DPFEM) is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the Minister for Police and Emergency Management, presently the Hon. [[Rene Hidding]] MP. The Department does not have a lead Secretary, with each agency reporting directly to the Minister.
The Department of Police, Fire and Emergency Management is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.police.tas.gov.au/about-us/ |title=About Us |work=[[Tasmania Police]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref> *Forensic Science Service Tas *[[Tasmania Fire Service]] *[[Tasmania Police]] *Tasmania State Emergency Service
==Premier and Cabinet== The '''Department of Premier and Cabinet''' (DPAC) is the central agency of the Tasmanian Government. The Department provides a broad range of services to Cabinet, other members of Parliament, Government agencies and the community. DPAC is headed by the [[Premier of Tasmania|Premier]], the Minister for Sport and Recreation, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, presently the Hon. [[Will Hodgman]] MP; supported by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Premier, presently [[Guy Barnett (Australian politician)|Guy Barnett]] MP; the Minister for Planning and Local Government, presently the Hon. [[Peter Gutwein]] MP; the Minister for Environment, Parks and Heritage, presently the Hon. [[Matthew Groom]] MP; the Minister for Information Technology and Innovation, presently the Hon. [[Michael Ferguson (Australian politician)|Michael Ferguson]] MP; and the Minister for Women, presently the Hon. [[Jacquie Petrusma]] MP.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dpac.tas.gov.au/department/about_us |title=About DPAC |work=Department of Premier and Cabinet |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department is led by its Secretary, Jenny Gale.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dpac.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/170149/DPAC_Org_Chart_Jun-2016.pdf |title=Organisation chart |work=Department of Premier and Cabinet |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment== The '''[[Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment (Tasmania)|Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and the Environment]]''' (DPIPWE) is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Water, and the Minister for Racing, presently the Hon. [[Jeremy Rockliff]] MP; supported by the Minister for Environment, Parks and Heritage, presently the Hon. [[Matthew Groom]] MP.<ref name=structureDPIPWE>{{cite web |url=http://dpipwe.tas.gov.au/about-the-department/structure-of-dpipwe |title=Structure of the Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment |work=[[Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment (Tasmania)|Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and the Environment]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=4 July 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department is led by its Secretary, John Whittington.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dpipwe.tas.gov.au/Documents/DPIPWE%20Org%20Chart.pdf |title=Organisational chart |work=[[Department of Primary Industries, Water and Environment (Tasmania)|Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and the Environment]] |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=July 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818204043/http://dpipwe.tas.gov.au/Documents/DPIPWE%20Org%20Chart.pdf# |archive-date=18 August 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and the Environment is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref name=structureDPIPWE/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Aboriginal Heritage Tasmania *AgriGrowth Tasmania *Biosecurity Tasmania *Environment Protection Authority Division *Heritage Tasmania *Inland Fisheries Service *Office of Racing Integrity *[[Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens]] *[[Tasmania Parks and Wildlife Service]] *Water & Marine Resources {{div col end}}
==State Growth== The '''[[Department of State Growth (Tasmania)|Department of State Growth]]''' is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the Minister for State Growth and the Minister for Energy, presently the Hon. [[Matthew Groom]] MP; supported by the Minister for Tourism, Hospitality and Events, presently the Hon. [[Will Hodgman]] MP; the Minister for Information Technology and Innovation, presently the Hon. [[Michael Ferguson (Australian politician)|Michael Ferguson]] MP; the Minister for the Arts, presently the Hon. Dr [[Vanessa Goodwin]] MLC; the Minister for Planning and Local Government, the Minister for Forestry, and the Minister for Building and Construction, presently the Hon. [[Peter Gutwein]] MP; the Minister for Infrastructure and the Minister for Mining, presently the Hon. [[Rene Hidding]] MP; and the Parliamentary Secretary for Small Business, presently the Hon. [[Guy Barnett (Australian politician)|Guy Barnett]] MP.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stategrowth.tas.gov.au/home/our_ministers |title=Our Ministers |work=Department of State Growth |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=12 July 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department is led by its Secretary, Kim Evans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stategrowth.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/129268/State_Growth_Organisational_Structure_@_19_January_2016.PDF |title=Organisational structure |work=Department of State Growth |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date=19 January 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016 }}</ref>
The Department of State Growth is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies: {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * Antarctic Tasmania * [[Arts Tasmania]] * Business Tasmania * Events Tasmania * Forest Practices Authority * [[Forestry Tasmania]] * [[Hydro Tasmania]] * Infrastructure Tasmania * [[Metro Tasmania]] * Mineral Resources Tasmania * Office of the Coordinator-General * [[Private Forests Tasmania]] * Racing Services Tasmania * Screen Tasmania * Skills Tasmania * Tasmanian Development Board * Tasmanian Institute of Sport * [[TasRail]] * [[Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery]] * Tourism Tasmania * [[TT-Line Company]] *[[West Coast Wilderness Railway]] {{div col end}}
==Treasury and Finance== The '''Department of Treasury and Finance''' is the lead agency of the portfolio headed by the [[Treasurer of Tasmania|Treasurer]], presently the Hon. [[Peter Gutwein]] MP.
The Department is led by its Secretary, Tony Ferrall.<ref name=DoTFabout>{{cite web |url=http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/domino/dtf/dtf.nsf/v-about/about |title=About us: Corporate Direction 2016-17 |work=Department of Treasury and Finance |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=15 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160717131813/http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/domino/dtf/dtf.nsf/v-about/about# |archive-date=17 July 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Department of Treasury and Finance is responsible for the following statutory and non-statutory bodies:<ref name=DoTFabout/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Office of the Tasmanian Economic Regulator]] *Retirement Benefits Fund *State Grants Commission *Tasmanian Liquor and Gaming Commission *Tasmanian Public Finance Corporation (Tascorp) {{div col end}}

[[File:Mount Yu Shan - Taiwan.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Taiwan]] is a mountainous island. The highest mountain is [[Jade Mountain]], seen here from the north peak. The main peak reaches the height of {{convert|3952|m|ft|0}}, that is, nearly {{convert|4|km|mi|1|abbr=on}} high.]]
[[Taiwan]] is a mountainous island. The island has the largest number and density of high mountains in the world. There are 286 mountain summits over {{convert|3000|m|ft|-2}} [[above sea level]] on the island, with [[Yushan (mountain)|Yushan]] being the tallest mountain in both Taiwan and East Asia. [[Mountaineering]] is one of the most popular activities for many [[Taiwanese people|Taiwanese]]. A list of [[100 Peaks of Taiwan]] was created in 1971, which lists the one hundred mountains over 3,000 m for mountaineering on the island. Climbing all of the one hundred mountains listed is considered the greatest challenge for Taiwanese climbers.
==Mountain ranges== There are five mountain ranges in the [[Geography of Taiwan|main island of Taiwan]] {|class=wikitable !Name!!Chinese!![[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]!![[Taiwanese Hakka|Hakka]]!!Highest point |- |[[Central Mountain Range]]||{{large|{{lang|zh-tw|中央山脈}}}}||Tiong-iong Soaⁿ-me̍h||Tûng-ông Sân-ma̍k|| {{convert|3860|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} — [[Xiuguluan Mountain]] |- |[[Yushan Range]]||{{large|{{lang|zh-tw|玉山山脈}}}}||Gio̍k-san Soaⁿ-me̍h||Ngiu̍k-Sân Sân-ma̍k|| {{convert|3952|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} — [[Yushan (mountain)|Jade Mountain]] |- |[[Xueshan Range]]||{{large|{{lang|zh-tw|雪山山脈}}}}||Suat-soaⁿ Soaⁿ-me̍h||Siet-sân Sân-ma̍k|| {{convert|3886|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} — [[Xueshan|Snow Mountain]] |- |[[Alishan Range]]||{{large|{{lang|zh-tw|阿里山山脈}}}}||A-lí-san Soaⁿ-me̍h||Â-lî-sân Sân-ma̍k|| {{convert|2663|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} — Data Mountain |- |[[Hai'an Range]]||{{large|{{lang|zh-tw|海岸山脈}}}}||Hái-hōaⁿ Soaⁿ-me̍h||Hói-ngan Sân-ma̍k|| {{convert|1682|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} — Xingang Mountain |}

==Other mountains== *[[Data Mountain]] 大塔山: {{convert|2663|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, the highest mountain of [[Alishan Range]], in [[Alishan, Chiayi|Alishan]], [[Chiayi County|Chiayi]]. *[[Taiping Mountain]] 太平山: {{convert|1950|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, a famous mountain in [[Datong, Yilan|Datong]], [[Yilan County, Taiwan|Yilan]]. *[[Xingang Mountain]] 新港山: {{convert|1682|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, the highest mountain of [[Haian Range|Hai'an Range]], in [[Fuli, Hualien|Fuli]], [[Hualien County|Hualian]].
===Volcanoes=== {{Main|List of volcanoes in Taiwan}}

==Mountain areas== *[[Alishan National Scenic Area]]: a famous mountain area in [[Alishan, Chiayi|Alishan]], [[Chiayi County|Chiayi]] and nearby townships. *[[Yangmingshan National Park]]: a famous mountain and volcano area in [[Beitou]] and [[Shilin District|Shilin]], [[Taipei City]] and nearby districts of [[New Taipei City]].
===Volcano areas (groups)=== *[[Tatun Volcano Group|Datun Volcano Area]] (Tatun Volcano Area): a [[volcano]] area in Yangmingshan National Park, Beitou and Shilin, Taipei City and nearby districts of New Taipei City. *[[Chilung Volcano Group|Keelung Volcano Area]] (Chilung or Jilong Volcano Area): a [[volcanic group|volcano area]] in [[Ruifang District|Ruifang]] and [[Shuangxi District|Shuangxi]], New Taipei City, near [[Keelung City]]. *[[Penghu Volcano Group|Penghu Volcano Area]] 澎湖火山區: a volcano area in [[Penghu County|Penghu]].

revision.text:
The following is a list of organizations for professionals involved in the practice of '''[[pharmacy]]'''. Such organizations are typically [[professional]] societies, as opposed to [[Industry trade group|trade associations]]. {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
<!-- ************************************************************************************************ --> <!-- Please do not add red links or external links. Source material in the form of external links are --> <!-- available in the history before May 1, 2009 for those wanting to create new articles on national --> <!-- pharmacy associations BEFORE adding them to the list. --> <!-- ************************************************************************************************ --> ==International== * [[International Pharmaceutical Federation]] (FIP) * [[International Pharmaceutical Students' Federation]] (IPSF)
==European== * [[European Association of Employed Community Pharmacists in Europe]] (EPhEU) * [[Pharmaceutical Group of the European Union]] (PGEU)
==Australia== * [[Australian College of Pharmacy]] ...... * [[Pharmaceutical Society of Australia]] * [[The Pharmacy Guild of Australia]] * [[The Society of Hospital Pharmacists of Australia]]
==Canada== * [[Canadian Pharmacists Association]] * [[Canadian Society of Hospital Pharmacists]] *[[Ontario Pharmacists Association]]

==Denmark== * [[Danish Association of Pharmaconomists]]
